function_call.name: classify_risks_framework
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Impact of indoor air quality and human comfort on the risk of malaria in retrofits, repairs, and building modifications.","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Buildings constructed using traditional materials are susceptible to mosquito intrusion","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Poor iaq can increase the risk of respiratory diseases.","category":"Air","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Reduced air exchanges due to modified building openings can lead to increased outdoor time and higher risk of mosquito exposure in malarious areas.","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Inadequate ventilation rates due to building modifications","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Unfavorable conditions for humans due to changes in building openings","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Leakage from temporary water supply points or improperly drained stormwater","category":"Water","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Ease of mosquito access to buildings through design features","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Poor indoor air quality iaq due to modifications in building openings","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Leakage from temporary water supply points or improperly drained storm water","category":"Water","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Malaria-causing mosquitoes access buildings through inlets and outlets, designed for air exchange","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Increased precipitation, relative humidity, and temperature conditions can create a more suitable habitat for the malaria vector.","category":"Water Cycle","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Pools of stagnant water developing in areas of intense excavation and earth removal work during the construction phase provide breeding grounds for malaria-causing mosquitoes.","category":"Water","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Selection of a site near an open surface water body increasing the number of breeding sites for the malaria vector","category":"Water","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Placement and size of building openings affecting vector accessibility","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Use of materials that increase vector attraction into the site","category":"Buildings/Blocks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Increase in warm or hot days coupled with flooding","category":"Water Cycle","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Deforestation increases the prevalence of the malaria vector, leading to a higher risk of malaria transmission.","category":"Nature","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Increased rainfall leads to increased prevalence of the anopheles vector, resulting in a greater need for malaria control strategies.","category":"Water","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Artificial breeding sites such as drains, gutters, swimming pools, and tire tracks can pose a risk for increased larvae development and greater mosquito population density.","category":"Water","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Deforestation from land use contributes to climate change, potentially altering the geographic distribution of disease vectors.","category":"Nature","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Link between increased construction activities and risk of malaria
